subject: 600th edition and still going ...
header: Last week, Team PWC celebrated the 200th week and today we are presenting 600th edition. Kudos to all the editors, current and past for the care and affections. It feels nice to be associated with such a popular events.

I would also like to thank all the die hard fans of the Perl Weekly Newsletter for their support and constructive suggestions from time to time. It really helps me to focus on things important to the readers. I know it is not easy to do this every week but the love and affection we get works like a magic.

I remember there was time when blogging was the only source of information but now a days we have plenty of platforms where you get usefull informations. You know what I mean and where you can catch us. I love having 2-ways dicussion on any topics related to Perl. It is something I always encourage if you have spare time. I have seen how young blood getting involved in so many exciting things about Perl, for example on Telegram. Although I don't get time to take part in the discussion but I do watch how the discussion follow through. I have senior member of Perl Community helping young blood with their experiences. It would be unfair to name few here. You know who I am talking about. I salute to all those who keep Perl alive.
If you have any ideas/suggestions then please do share with us. I would to hear your point of views. Enjoy the rest of the newsletter till then.

entries.title: This Week in PSC (094)
entries.text: I love getting regular update by the Perl Steering Council. Every minute details are now public. Well done.

entries.title: OTOBO supports the German Perl/Raku-Workshop
entries.author: max_maischein
entries.text: Happy to see GPW getting support of OTOBO. You should attend the workshop if you can. It is not just for German speaking audience. I have attended once in the past too.

entries.title: Retirement Announcement - Dave Rolsky
entries.author: amber_deuel
entries.text: After several years of service to The Perl/Raku Foundation, Dave Rolsky is retiring. The board thanks Dave for all of his work, he will be missed.

entries.title: Using Perl to prepare sequencing files to submit to NCBI's GEO
entries.author: chrisarg
entries.text: Pleasantly surprised to see how Perl can be used is so many different fields.

entries.title: Util::H2O and More, during Ordinary Times
entries.author: oodler
entries.text: Nice to see, Perl Advent Calendar post is still being discussed today. We should all share the work done by the Perl community with the rest of the world.

entries.title: My Family and Other Fish (PerlayStation Part 2)
entries.author: saif_ahmed
entries.text: Good to see Saif is back. I find the subject very engaging and ofcouse his style of writing takes it to another level..

entries.title: Regexp Delimiters
entries.author: tom_wyant
entries.text: Looking at regexp through the lens of Perl is always fun. You will never get bored.

entries.author: flavio_poletti
entries.text: Did you know about Synacor Challenge? I didn't. Find out more in the blog post.
entries.title: Synacor Challenge - my repo

entries.author: flavio_poletti
entries.text: Another tool for hobby-scale projects. Interesting, worth checking.
entries.title: KnowTee - easy notifications

chapters.title: The Weekly Challenge
chapters.header: The Weekly Challenge by Mohammad Anwar will help you step out of your comfort-zone. You can even win prize money of $50 Amazon voucher by participating in the weekly challenge. We pick one winner at the end of the month from among all of the contributors during the month. The monthly prize is kindly sponsored by Peter Sergeant of PerlCareers.

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Missing Numbers" and "Penny Piles". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.
entries.title: The Weekly Challenge - 201

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Arithmetic Slices" and "Seven Segment 200" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.
entries.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 200

entries.author: arne_sommer
entries.text: The verbose version of solution is worth checking. Keep it up great work.
entries.title: Seven Angry Slices

entries.author: colin_crain
entries.text: The background story of task is something you don't want to miss it. I loved it. Thank you Colin.
entries.title: Seven Segments to Midnight

entries.author: dave_jacoby
entries.text: Loop is the flavour of the week. Complicated solutions can be solved using simple loops. Well done.
entries.title: Bicent-Weekly Solution

entries.author: david_ferrone
entries.text: Nice to know how Perl and Raku behave differently at times. Thanks for sharing your experience.
entries.title: Weekly Challenge 200

entries.author: flavio_poletti
entries.text: No question from Flavio this week. Straight to the solution in Perl and Raku. Thank you.
entries.title: PWC200 - Arithmetic Slices

entries.author: flavio_poletti
entries.text: Good use of state in the solution. Thanks for sharing.
entries.title: PWC200 - Seven Segment 200

entries.author: james_smith
entries.text: We missed the performance stats this week. Never mind, we still have top notch solution.
entries.title: The Weekly Challenge 200

entries.author: laurent_rosenfeld
entries.text: Plenty of demo makes it crystal clear how the code works. Cool attempt. Keep it up.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 200: Arithmetic Slices and Seven Segment Display

entries.author: luca_ferrari
entries.text: Easy route picked up by Luca, still not a bad attempt. Thanks for your contributions.
entries.title: not optimal!

entries.author: luis_mochan
entries.text: Use of binary mask is good choice. I liked it, thanks for sharing.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 200

entries.author: peter_campbell_smith
entries.text: The simplest solution yet very compact. I am impressed. Well done.
entries.title: Slicing and dicing a double century

entries.author: robbie_hatley
entries.text: Robbie found task #2 easier than task #1. It was supposed to the otherway around. Still we got two nice solutions. Thank you.
entries.title: The Weekly Challenge #200

entries.author: roger_bell_west
entries.text: Use of bitmap table is really nice. Thanks for sharing your knowledge with us.
entries.title: Seven Slices

entries.author: simon_green
entries.text: Thank you for spreading the work on dev.to site and your kind message. We got the usual collection of Perl and Python, deadly combination.
entries.title: Two hundred slices

entries.author: stephen_lynn
entries.text: I liked the various different approaches being used by all. Steve came up with simple string to solve the task. Nice one.
entries.title: PWC 200

chapters.title: Perl Tutorial
chapters.header: A section for newbies and for people who need some refreshing of their Perl knowledge. If you have questions or suggestions about the articles, let me know and I'll try to make the necessary changes. The included articles are from the Perl Maven Tutorial and are part of the Perl Maven eBook.
